topics.body:
Speaking about philosophy here's a interesting paradox:
You know the "ship of Theseus"?  Essentially if you replace every part of a ship is it the same ship?

The paradox is that every 7 years every cell in your body is replaced; so if you believe in the ship of Theseus then wouldn't that mean you're literally a different person than when you were a child?
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/556267af6368722d38bc0900#post_556267af6368722d38bc0900
"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/556268106368722d4d120900#post_556268106368722d4d120900
I just thought it was interesting and pertinent to science in modern day because you know how I never shut up about biomechatronics?  Well they're already working on neural enhancement prototypes with memristors.  Basically in say idunno 40-50 years you'll be able to replace your entire brain with a computer.  When the technology eventually reaches market it will probably at first start out as augmentations, like intelligence boosters or such though and slowly move towards replacements.  Essentially if you replace parts of your brain with a computer are you still "you"?

Actually that was the story of ghost in the shell movie 1 and it's actually expanded further and further in the series as time has gone on.  The latest movie a hacker named scarecrow dubbed his "soul" into other bodies repetitively and wound up in "tinman"'s brain and as a result the original brains of both of them no longer existed.

Essentially if you can completely replace your brain with a computer are you still you?

topics.body:
Anyway; going back to what I was talking about the memristors and that.  The reason why memristors and that are relevant to cyborgs is that I read a article by IEET (a neuroscience organization).  Essentially if we do develop the technology to replace the human brain it won't be copying a person's mind, rather it would be a rapid streaming into the new body.

Essentially less of a Glados thing where they copy the person's mind and more of a: doctor, "are you ready for the transfer?" patient, "yes" *click* *originally body thudding on the ground cause it no longer has a mind* patient, "when are you going to start" doctor, "we've already finished; look at your body" patient, "Damn!  That was fast!"


The reason why we can't do it currently is because we don't have the technology to house a entire conscious and that the human brain doesn't have a peripheral port to transfer information so we have to invent one.

What they're working on isn't the scan and copy type where the original is destroyed, but rather streaming the information.  When the technology is eventually developed in say 40 years it will still be a ultra complicated procedure with like millions of small wires coming out of the person's skull and that for rapid streaming.

Tl:dr; if in 40 years we have the technology to replace the human brain it probably is going to rapidly stream a conscious from the human brain to a machine brain and won't be destructive scan and copy, but rather like sucking the mind out of the brain like with a tube and putting it in the new machine brain.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
